children.name: Polynomial time: problems that can be solved by a Turing machine whose running time is ≤ p(n) for some polynomial p.

children.name: Polynomial space: problems that can be solved by a Turing machine whose space complexity is ≤ p(n) for some polynomial p.
keywords: Polynomial space: problems that can be solved by a Turing machine whose space complexity is ≤ p(n) for some polynomial p.

children.name: Main observation: The number of configurations of a PSpace machine is at most exponential, and it is enough to consider computations without loops.
keywords: Main observation: The number of configurations of a PSpace machine is at most exponential, and it is enough to consider computations without loops.

children.name: We can simply run it M, while counting the number of steps, and reject once the exponential bound is exceeded.
keywords: We can simply run it M, while counting the number of steps, and reject once the exponential bound is exceeded.

children.name: By the Sipser theorem (see later), this will not be needed.
keywords: By the Sipser theorem (see later), this will not be needed.

children.name: Also works for nondeterministic PSpace: explore the tree of all computations, using depth-first search, with an exponential bound on recursion depth.
keywords: Also works for nondeterministic PSpace: explore the tree of all computations, using depth-first search, with an exponential bound on recursion depth.

children.name: Savitch’s theorem: Nondeterministic polynomial space = deterministic polynomial space
keywords: Savitch’s theorem: Nondeterministic polynomial space = deterministic polynomial space

children.name: To prove Savitch’s theorem, for a nondeterministic Turing machine that runs in space p(n), we run this program for: source = initial configuration target = accepting configuration n = log k × p(n) m = p(n)
keywords: To prove Savitch’s theorem, for a nondeterministic Turing machine that runs in space p(n), we run this program for: source = initial configuration target = accepting configuration n = log k × p(n) m = p(n)

children.name: Sipser’s theorem: machines with finite space can be forced to halt
keywords: Sipser’s theorem: machines with finite space can be forced to halt

children.name: Theorem (Sipser). For every deterministic Turing machine M, there is a deterministic Turing machine N such that for every input word:
keywords: Theorem (Sipser). For every deterministic Turing machine M, there is a deterministic Turing machine N such that for every input word:

children.name: 1. M accepts if and only if N accepts
keywords: 1. M accepts if and only if N accepts

children.name: 2. if M uses n < ∞ memory cells, then N halts and also uses n cells.
keywords: 2. if M uses n < ∞ memory cells, then N halts and also uses n cells.

children.name: Consider the graph of configurations that use memory ≤ m
keywords: Consider the graph of configurations that use memory ≤ m

children.name: each component is either a tree...
keywords: each component is either a tree...

children.name: A terminal in this graph is a vertex of outdegree 0.
keywords: A terminal in this graph is a vertex of outdegree 0.

children.name: Solution: Start in the accepting configuration, and search the tree (dfs) for the initial configuration.
keywords: Solution: Start in the accepting configuration, and search the tree (dfs) for the initial configuration.

children.name: Solution: Start in the accepting configuration, and search the tree (dfs) for the initial configuration.
keywords: Solution: Start in the accepting configuration, and search the tree (dfs) for the initial configuration.

children.name: If there are 0 such terminals, the machine loops in memory ≤ m.
keywords: If there are 0 such terminals, the machine loops in memory ≤ m.

children.name: If there is 1 such terminal, we can reject, accept, or increment m.
keywords: If there is 1 such terminal, we can reject, accept, or increment m.

children.name: The simulating machine remembers in its state which neighbour it has visited in the previous step.
keywords: The simulating machine remembers in its state which neighbour it has visited in the previous step.

children.name: The work tape has size at most log(poly n)
keywords: The work tape has size at most log(poly n)

children.name: There is a nondeterministic logspace machine which does the following:
keywords: There is a nondeterministic logspace machine which does the following:

children.name: input: a directed graph, with a designated source vertex
keywords: input: a directed graph, with a designated source vertex

children.name: output: the number of vertices reachable from the source
keywords: output: the number of vertices reachable from the source

children.name: on every input, the machine has a unique accepting run, and the output number is found on the work tape, in binary
keywords: on every input, the machine has a unique accepting run, and the output number is found on the work tape, in binary

children.name: guesses if the vertex u is reachable via a path of at most d–1 edges. If the guess is wrong, the program will eventually fail.
keywords: guesses if the vertex u is reachable via a path of at most d–1 edges. If the guess is wrong, the program will eventually fail.

children.name: a subroutine that can be done in nondeterministic logspace
keywords: a subroutine that can be done in nondeterministic logspace

children.name: if there was an incorrect “true” guess, then this will fail
keywords: if there was an incorrect “true” guess, then this will fail

children.name: if there was an incorrect “false” guess, then this will fail
keywords: if there was an incorrect “false” guess, then this will fail

children.name: Consider a language L, whose complement is recognised by a nondeterministic logspace Turing machine M.
keywords: Consider a language L, whose complement is recognised by a nondeterministic logspace Turing machine M.

children.name: (1) on the graph of configurations of M
keywords: (1) on the graph of configurations of M

children.name: (2) on the graph of configurations of M, with accepting configurations removed
keywords: (2) on the graph of configurations of M, with accepting configurations removed

children.name: If the results are equal (i.e. M rejects), then accept, otherwise reject.
keywords: If the results are equal (i.e. M rejects), then accept, otherwise reject.
